title: How to Make Decoupage Eggs

steps.headline: Poke a small hole in the pointed end of one egg.
steps.description: Poke a larger hole on the rounder end of the egg.

steps.headline: Hold the egg over a bowl.
steps.description: Blow the contents out carefully through the larger end.

steps.headline: Repeat with as many eggs as you're making.
Wash the eggs with care.
steps.description: Allow to air dry on a drying rack. They can also be gently dabbed with a cloth or paper towel.

parts.name: Cutting the Paper and Sealing the Eggs

steps.headline: Cut the origami paper sheets into small triangles of the same size.
steps.description: You can draw a triangle on but after a few cuts, you'll get used to doing this without having to follow a template.

steps.headline: Put a little glue into a dish.
steps.description: Add a bit of water to thin it; mix together. Paint this over the egg and any other eggs. This seals the surface of the eggs. Place the glued egg inside a shot glass to dry.

steps.headline: Brush the back of each piece of paper with glue.
Press the first piece gently onto the first egg.
steps.description: Smooth it from the center out to the edges, to remove any air bubbles and to ensure that it is sticking properly.

steps.headline: Glue the remaining triangles onto the egg.
steps.description: Overlap the edges to ensure that the egg surface is completely covered up.

steps.headline: Repeat with the remaining eggs you're making.
Allow to dry.
steps.description: When dry, brush each egg entirely with a coat of the thinned glue. Let dry completely. This seals the paper and prevents it from curling up or getting damaged if it's accidentally sprayed or gets a little wet.

steps.headline: Place on display.
steps.description: These eggs would look great inside a glass bowl, on a cake stand, inside a tall wide vase or in other decorative uses as you'd like. Done.
